The judge has said, no way! You can't change your plea! Good.
 
 It is costing the Minn. airport 25k per stall to change the walls from floor to ceiling to protect the innocent from folks like Larry Craig now and during next year's republican convention.

 
 I don't find anything to rejoice about in what has happened to Larry Craig. Whatever we may think of Craig's closeted life or his support for anti-gay causes and the Republican agenda, Craig was unfairly entrapped by the police. He is being heaved over the side by his Republican colleagues for what? For tapping his foot and sending signals. He is being heaved over the side because he asked someone for sex. In a country where we supposedly have freedom, why is this a crime? And why should someone be made to feel so ashamed of being gay and so intent on hiding who he is that he resorts to asking strangers for sex in a public restroom in the first place? 
 
 Certainly Craig was foolish to plead guilty as he did, and to believe that doing so would make the incident go away quietly. Craig should have known better. And we can certainly denounce Craig, as we have, for being a hypocrite and for promoting anti-gay legislation while pretending to be heterosexual. We can denounce him for continuing to lie about himself to the public, when everyone can see the truth. 
 
 But Larry Craig does not deserve what is being done to him. The homophobes in his own party, people who were supposedly his friends, are dumping him overboard to serve their own political purposes. Some friends. 
 
 The people we should be criticizing are the Republican leaders who are so homophobic, they do this to their supposed friend and colleague. They embrace bigotry in service of their own political gain. What kind of values are those?
 
 I think that we gay folks should stand up for Larry Craig and denounce the injustice that is being done to him, both by the police in Minnesota and by many of his fellow Republicans. Craig has not been our ally; quite the opposite. But he is the victim of homophobic attacks, and I think we should speak out against that.
JSDKoeln

Craig has not been our ally; quite the opposite. But he is the victim of homophobic attacks, and I think we should speak out against that.

 
 Where I find this loser so disgusting, I am failing to understand just what the crime was. I thought the law was not to have actual sex in a bathroom. He can proposition whomever he wants till he's blue in the face, but if he did not have sex, he did not have sex. 
 
 But on the other hand, it is very telling of the "christian" conservative party where forgiveness is tauted and "hate the sin, love the sinner" is professed ad nauseum. Maybe this blatent hypocricy will finally start seeping into some of those rigid, conservative minds.
Matthew S

 Certainly Craig was foolish to plead guilty as he did, and to believe that doing so would make the incident go away quietly. Craig should have known better. And we can certainly denounce Craig, as we have, for being a hypocrite and for promoting anti-gay legislation while pretending to be heterosexual.  I agree he did nothing wrong and even if he had engaged in sex still he would have done nothing wrong. Public sex is not morally wrong and should not be illegal.
 
 As far as gay people comming to his defense, well.......don't you think that is a little like Dorothy comming to the defense of the wicked witch of the west?
Ohioprof

I agree he did nothing wrong and even if he had engaged in sex still he would have done nothing wrong. Public sex is not morally wrong and should not be illegal.
 
 As far as gay people comming to his defense, well.......don't you think that is a little like Dorothy comming to the defense of the wicked witch of the west?

 
 It's like Dorothy defending the wicked witch after the witch has been unfairly entrapped by the police. Even the worst hypocrites deserve fair treatment, and we all need to stick up for the liberty to ask someone for something, including sex.
 
 It strikes me that what Larry Craig did in the bathroom, while foolish, harmed no one and is no big deal. What the police did IS a big deal, because it threatens the personal liberty of all of us, and I mean all Americans, not just gay people. And what the Republican leaders are doing is just blatant targeting of a colleague because he is gay, and THAT is truly immoral activity. 
 
 Larry Craig is not the same as Mark Foley. Craig was not hitting on someone underage or someone the Congress was entrusted to look out for. Craig asked an adult if he wanted to have sex. Not sex for money, just freely exchanged sex. Why should asking someone for sex be a crime?

What the police did IS a big deal, because it threatens the personal liberty of all of us, and I mean all Americans, not just gay people. And what the Republican leaders are doing is just blatant targeting of a colleague because he is gay, and THAT is truly immoral activity. 
 
 Larry Craig is not the same as Mark Foley. Craig was not hitting on someone underage or someone the Congress was entrusted to look out for. Craig asked an adult if he wanted to have sex. Not sex for money, just freely exchanged sex. Why should asking someone for sex be a crime?

 
 Because, according to the Larry Craig's of this world, sex is to be shared only in the bonds of matrimony. This is what he's supported and his hypocrisy is not something, IMHO, that anyone should support.
jyoshu

I don't find anything to rejoice about in what has happened to Larry Craig. Whatever we may think of Craig's closeted life or his support for anti-gay causes and the Republican agenda, Craig was unfairly entrapped by the police.
 
 He is being heaved over the side by his Republican colleagues for what? For tapping his foot and sending signals. He is being heaved over the side because he asked someone for sex.

 
 I have to say, this is one case I tend to agree with you nearly 100%. And that doesn't really happen that often! I agree he was indeed entrapped and and I think he was pressured somewhat into the plea he gave. Why is this any different than other cases where police have gone after and entrapped gay people unfairly? 
 
 I will say however, it's not just homophobes in his own party though; it's people on both sides of the aisle. Republicans may be trying to dump him, but some gay rights people are also trying to use the situation as another "hypocrisy-police" opportunity. This is one of those cases where either group could rise about the fray and do the right thing, and show some compassion to this guy. In terms of you feeling that the blame should be levied toward Republicans, do you really think Democrats would be happy to see this man switch to their ranks, and that they would take him in with open arms? I don't think so. As long as he's a political liability, neither party is going to be open to having him, unfortunately.
 
 This case has bugged me from the beginning, because I think this guy was entrapped, an people are trying use the situation for their own agendas. In some ways, I hope he DOES stay in the senate just to be defiant to those who want him to leave. He was arrested and being castigated over things like toe-tapping and running a hand under the edge of a stall. It makes me want to say to people "get a life."
Ohioprof

I have to say, this is one case I tend to agree with you nearly 100%. And that doesn't really happen that often! I agree he was indeed entrapped and and I think he was pressured somewhat into the plea he gave. Why is this any different than other cases where police have gone after and entrapped gay people unfairly? 
 
 I will say however, it's not just homophobes in his own party though; it's people on both sides of the aisle. Republicans may be trying to dump him, but some gay rights people are also trying to use the situation as another "hypocrisy-police" opportunity. This is one of those cases where either group could rise about the fray and do the right thing, and show some compassion to this guy. In terms of you feeling that the blame should be levied toward Republicans, do you really think Democrats would be happy to see this man switch to their ranks, and that they would take him in with open arms? I don't think so. As long as he's a political liability, neither party is going to be open to having him, unfortunately.

 
 But the reality is that it ISN'T the Democrats who are howling for him to step down. It's the Republicans. To imagine that the Democrats would do the same thing is just imagining. The Republican leadership really IS doing this to Craig. 
 
 The position of gay people in the Democratic Party is different from their position in the Republican Party. There are plenty of gay Republican political leaders, but they are almost universally closeted. The Republican leadership demands that they be closeted, to keep from offending their religious right base. The Democratic Party allows for, and probably expects, gay political leaders to be open about their sexual orientation. Democratic political leaders, as avowed supporters of gay rights, tend to expect gay people in their party NOT to be closeted. They would probably reject someone like Larry Craig not because he is gay, but because he insists that he isn't gay and he votes against gay rights measures while living an apparent double life.
jyoshu

If Larry Craig was a Democrat, we'd be hearing a lot from liberals in the media about how he was bravely exploring his sexual identity. We would hear indignant objections to this policeman who, obviously having nothing better to do with his time, was doing surveillance in airport bathrooms in search of innocent people to harass and victimize. The ACLU would be right in there, asking about Craig's right to privacy and wondering why such ambiguous evidence (he placed his bag in front of the door, he tapped his foot) was enough to warrant arrest and prosecution. Even Craig's guilty plea would be employed in his favor: look, the man is at least being honest about what he did, and why should he be ashamed of being who he is? If Larry Craig was a Democrat, the system, not Craig, would be on trial.
 
 Unfortunately for Larry Craig, he is a Republican and a conservative to boot. We've been hearing a lot about conservative hypocrisy in the past several days: turning on CNN, I saw anchor Soledad O' Brien, correspondent Candy Crowley and legal pundit Jeff Toobin all having a great time with the subject. None of them saw fit to comment on the Himalayan hypocrisy of the liberals, undoubtedly because they embodied it.
 
 So where is the liberal hypocrisy? Consider: the cardinal values of today's liberalism are the right to personal freedom, the right of consenting adults to do what they want as long as they do not trespass on the rights of others, and the right to privacy. Larry Craig's conduct may have been unseemly, but he did not violate any of the liberal values. He wasn't assaulting the man in the other stall, he was approaching him to seek his consent. Whatever he was doing, he wasn't doing it in the Oval Office like Clinton but in a men's room stall. Notwithstanding the obscure "signaling" that was apparently going on, Craig didn't actually engage in any kind of sexual activity. No cigars were inserted into any private orifices. Craig's home, in contrast with Barney Frank's apartment, was not used as a full-service prostitution venue. Craig hasn't figured out, like Gerry Studds, that you don't have to forage in airport restrooms when there are pages to be turned over on Capitol Hill itself.
 
 In all those cases--Barney Frank, Gerry Studds, Bill Clinton--liberals rushed to the defense of their guys and proceeded to attack their critics as the real threat to civil liberties and social freedom. (Bill Clinton's approval ratings on the left actually rose when his sexual misconduct came to public light.) Therefore in the Larry Craig case, liberal indignation stands exposed as largely opportunistic. Here is a chance to hoist the conservatives on their own petard, to hang another scandal on the necks of the GOP, and to undermine the case for moral standards in society under the pretext of upholding them." - by Dinesh D'Souza
 http://news.aol.com/newsbloggers/2007/09/04/if-larry-craig-was-a-democrat/

post_info.post_title: If Larry Craig Was a Democrat...

jyoshu

But the reality is that it ISN'T the Democrats who are howling for him to step down. It's the Republicans. To imagine that the Democrats would do the same thing is just imagining. The Republican leadership really IS doing this to Craig. 
 
 The position of gay people in the Democratic Party is different from their position in the Republican Party. There are plenty of gay Republican political leaders, but they are almost universally closeted. The Republican leadership demands that they be closeted, to keep from offending their religious right base. The Democratic Party allows for, and probably expects, gay political leaders to be open about their sexual orientation. Democratic political leaders, as avowed supporters of gay rights, tend to expect gay people in their party NOT to be closeted. They would probably reject someone like Larry Craig not because he is gay, but because he insists that he isn't gay and he votes against gay rights measures while living an apparent double life.

 
 Respectfully, I think you are missing the point here. The reason that Democrats would not want this man in their ranks is not because he is or isn't gay. (There is no way to even prove whether or not he is or isn't gay--Craig himself emphatically say he isn't.) It's because he now carries political baggage than can be a liability. Accurate or not, Craig now has a federal charge of misconduct of lewd behavior on his record. And he is a media lightning rod at the moment, and there is no way the Democrats would want to deal with that, any more than Republicans. They want nothing to do with this issue, or with Craig, which is why they've been pretty silent overall on the matter.
samiinh

Respectfully, I think you are missing the point here. The reason that Democrats would not want this man in their ranks is not because he is or isn't gay. (There is no way to even prove whether or not he is or isn't gay--Craig himself emphatically say he isn't.) It's because he now carries political baggage than can be a liability. Accurate or not, Craig now has a federal charge of misconduct of lewd behavior on his record. And he is a media lightning rod at the moment, and there is no way the Democrats would want to deal with that, any more than Republicans. They want nothing to do with this issue, or with Craig, which is why they've been pretty silent overall on the matter.

 
 Craig is a creep and it's a wonder how he ever got elected in the first place.
Ohioprof

Respectfully, I think you are missing the point here. The reason that Democrats would not want this man in their ranks is not because he is or isn't gay. (There is no way to even prove whether or not he is or isn't gay--Craig himself emphatically say he isn't.) It's because he now carries political baggage than can be a liability. Accurate or not, Craig now has a federal charge of misconduct of lewd behavior on his record. And he is a media lightning rod at the moment, and there is no way the Democrats would want to deal with that, any more than Republicans. They want nothing to do with this issue, or with Craig, which is why they've been pretty silent overall on the matter.

 
 Well, your whole scenario of "what would the Democrats do with Craig" is imaginary, as Craig is not a Democrat and he doesn't appear to want to become a Democrat. If Craig were a Democrat to begin with, he would have less reason to be closeted, since the Democrats don't try to appeal to a base that demands that gay people be repudiated and excluded. I'm not saying there are no closeted gay Democratic political leaders living double lives. Look at James McGreevey. However, that's beside the point, because Craig is a Republican and not a Democrat. Craig is a Republican probably because he believes in most of the values and positions of that party. And there is just about no place within the Republican Party for an aspiring politician who believes in most Republican values and positions and who happens to be gay, other than deep in the closet. The Democrats have at least opened the closet door a bit, and openly gay people do run as Democratic candidates with the blessing of party leaders. 
 
 Politically it's smart for Democratic leaders to be silent about Larry Craig, to let the Republicans target each other over this. It certainly benefits the Democratic Party. Whether it's moral to be silent is another question. I think we as ordinary gay citizens and heterosexual citizens should speak out against the kind of police entrapment that Larry Craig endured, and we should speak out against the way Craig is being treated by leaders in his own party, with a few exceptions like Arlen Specter. I admire Arlen Specter for standing up for and with Craig on this.
Ohioprof

Craig is a creep and it's a wonder how he ever got elected in the first place.

 
 Whether he is a creep or not, he has still been treated terribly unfairly by the police and by most Republican leaders. He is clearly a victim of Republican homophobia. And yes, it IS Republican homophobia, not Democratic homophobia. Democratic leaders may sin to some degree through their silence, but the sin of Republican leaders is far greater. Most Republican leaders are pitching a colleague overboard because his ineptitude has led to the public revelation that he is gay. They are not treating the heterosexual Vitter the way they are treating Craig, because Vitter is not gay. That's Republican homophobia, and it's ugly.
Sigma

This case has bugged me from the beginning, because I think this guy was entrapped, an people are trying use the situation for their own agendas. In some ways, I hope he DOES stay in the senate just to be defiant to those who want him to leave. 

 
 I disagree. Regardless of what he did or how unfair it is or is not, he should resign if for no other reason than he said he would if his plea was not retracted.
chemist99a

Craig is a creep and it's a wonder how he ever got elected in the first place.

 
 ANd oddly enough if he completes this term he will have served more terms than any other Senator from his state. Why do they keep electing him if he is such a creep? Don't you think that rather strange?

 Indeed I do...what does it say about Idaho?

 I agree that we should not support his hypocrisy. But I do think we should support him and anyone who is unfairly entrapped by the police. I also think we should decry the Republican leaders who seek to dump him because he is gay, which they are not doing to the heterosexual Vitter.

 While I agree that Craig was a victim of entrapment, and that his arrest and conviction were grossly unfair (and even, maybe, dare I suggest, unconstitutional as he wasn't even having sex in public!), he's basically a victim of the anti-gay culture he and his party have praised and promoted. As such, I really see some karma or cosmic justice here, the wolf bitten, and have relatively little sympathy.
 
 Since he can't even bring himself to admit he has homosexual desires, I don't see him as one of my own, either. He's neither fish nor fowl, some other kind of meat entirely, and not particularly savoury. Still, as long as he's around to make headaches for the GOP, he has some saving graces! ;)

 Evil? C'mon. The Vitter-Craig scandal is just evidence that the GOP is a pack of liars when it comes to their stance of being the value/moral party.

The Honorable Larry E. Craig
 United States Senator, Idaho
 Specialty Recipe
 Super Tuber
 
 Super Tuber is a great snack that uses one of my favorite vegetables: The Idaho Potato. Of course, I suppose any type of potato could be used, but I cannot guarantee that a Super Tuber made with anything but a true Idaho potato would taste as good. Sincerely, Larry E. Craig, United States Senator
 
 Ingredients
 1 hot dog, cook's choice
 1 Idaho baking potato, 7 to 10 ounces
 Mustard for dipping, any style
 Other condiments as desired such as cheese sauce, sour cream, chili, chives, bacon pieces or black olives.
 
 Wash and dry potato. Rub with shortening or butter. With an apple corer or small knife, core out the potato center (end to end). Push hot dog through the center. Bake until potato is cooked through.

EXCLUSIVE: "I Had Sex with Larry Craig!"
 
 Would you let this man screw your senator?We've been having loads of fun with gay restroom goblin Larry Craig over the past couple of months, haven't we? What we've been missing, though, is an on-the-record account from a source willing to come forward and tell what it's like to have an actual romantic liaison with the Idaho Republican. Meet David Phillips, a local IT geek and bear-about-town.
 
 Phillips was recently in a bar minding his own business when he heard Craig's voice on the television. "I went pale and nearly vomited," Phillips says. It was the man he remembered from one of his creepiest sexual encounters twenty years earlier. "After a truncated meal I went back to my hotel room and began unwinding and jotting down the memories that the voice had opened. I recalled The Follies, the furtive groping and pawing there, the odd following of this man in my car..... ####!"
 http://wonkette.com/politics/larry-craig-scandal/exclusive-i-had-sex-with-larry-craig-314897.php
